instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: Would an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board (2013 retina MacBook Pro) work without a hall sensor?
threads.message:
Hey guys

So I bought a liquid damaged MacBook Pro on eBay. Originally it had no 3V42 but after I fixed that I noticed that the display would flicker. 
This Mac isn't intended for resale, I just need a Mac. Would the board work as expected if I were to remove the hall sensor with the exception of turning the screen off when you close the lid? I don't have any donor boards and I don't want to wait for Chinese shipping. The sensor looked pretty terrible so I have a feeling that's whats bad. Thanks!

threads.title: Would an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board (2013 retina MacBook Pro) work without a hall sensor?
threads.message:
Apart of no reaction from lid, machine will work good.
But easy to check if <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signal fluctuates.
You could have problems with backlight circuit instead.
